turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about USS Cyclops (AC-4).
turn.2: USS Cyclops (AC-4) USS "Cyclops" (AC-4) was the second of four "Proteus"-class colliers built for the United States Navy several years before World War I.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: Named for the Cyclops, a primordial race of giants from Greek mythology, she was the second U.S. Naval vessel to bear the name.
turn.5: What was the most interesting part of the article?
turn.6: The loss of the ship and 306 crew and passengers without a trace within the area known as the Bermuda Triangle some time after 4 March 1918 remains the single largest loss of life in U.S. Naval history not directly involving combat.
turn.7: Did they ever find out what happened to it?
turn.8: As it was wartime, she was thought to have been captured or sunk by a German raider or submarine, because she was carrying of manganese ore used to produce munitions, but German authorities at the time, and subsequently, denied any knowledge of the vessel.
turn.10: The Naval History & Heritage Command has stated she "probably sank in an unexpected storm", but the ultimate cause of the ship's loss is not known.
turn.12: "Cyclops" was launched on 7 May 1910, by William Cramp & Sons of Philadelphia and placed in service on 7 November 1910, with Lieutenant Commander George Worley, Master, Naval Auxiliary Service, in command.
